content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}

Now given a task: Find the ArXiv Blog on the ArXiv website and summarize the content of its latest article.  Please interact with https://arxiv.org/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: There is no link or mention of a "Blog" visible in this portion of the homepage. The current screen primarily shows search options and subject browse options. To find the ArXiv Blog, I may need to scroll down or look for navigation links or footers that typically contain links to external pages like a blog.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.1
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Still no explicit link or reference to an "ArXiv Blog" is visible in the current view. The content continues to show categories and browsing options for academic subjects. Proceeding to scroll further down may reveal footer links or information/navigation typically found at the bottom of web pages, which often include links to blogs or news.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The current view continues to display academic categories and research sections. There is no sign of a blog link or section yet. Since navigation or informative links are often located at the very bottom of a website (footer), another scroll down is necessary to locate the ArXiv Blog.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.25
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: There still isn't an explicit "Blog" link, but the links in the "About arXiv" and footer may lead to further information about the blog. The "General information" or "Who We Are" (label [28] or [32]) are likely to include such links, but it's more common for a blog to be promoted in a general info or news section. I should check "General information" first for any mention of the blog.
Action: Click [28]
Confidence: 0.85
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The "General information" section leads to "About arXiv," which gives a general site overview. However, there is no mention of a blog here. The sidebar ("Table of contents") includes a "News" section (label [5]), which might either include or link to the blog or contain blog-like updates, as sometimes news and blog content are interlinked on academic sites.
Action: Click [5]
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.4
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The "arXiv Blog" link is now clearly visible under the "News" section, label [9]. Clicking this link should take me directly to the arXiv Blog, where I can then look for the latest article and summarize its content.
Action: Click [9]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.6

content:
Thought: The latest article is titled "Attention Authors: Upcoming Scheduled Maintenance to arxiv.org" with a publication date of September 16, 2025. The visible summary mentions a scheduled maintenance that will take place on September 17th, 2025, detailing the hours (7AM–9AM EDT) and notes that site functions requiring login will be disabled during this time. I should click "CONTINUE READING" (label [9]) to ensure I get the full details for a complete summary.
Action: Click [9]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.85

content:
Thought: The article "Attention Authors: Upcoming Scheduled Maintenance to arxiv.org" is confirmed as the latest blog post. The visible content reiterates the upcoming scheduled maintenance for the arXiv database on September 17th, 2025, from 7AM to 9AM EDT. All login-required functions, including submissions and account access, will be disabled, but browsing and searching are still possible. I should scroll down to ensure I capture any additional important details for the summary.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.9

Note that <textarea> or <input> may be textbox, but not exactly. Please focus more on the screenshot and then refer to the textual information.

content:
Thought: The full article is now visible, confirming the details about the scheduled maintenance on arXiv.org. Authors are explicitly warned they won't be able to log in or submit during the maintenance window as servers are upgraded. There is a link for live status updates. No further article content appears; the rest of the page is navigation or comment section. I am ready to summarize the content for the ANSWER.
Action: ANSWER; The latest article on the arXiv Blog, "Attention Authors: Upcoming Scheduled Maintenance to arxiv.org" (published September 16, 2025), announces that arXiv’s database will undergo scheduled maintenance on September 17th, 2025, from 7AM to 9AM EDT. During this window, users will be able to browse and search the site, but all functions requiring login—including submissions, account editing, and endorsements—will be disabled. Authors are advised that submissions will not be possible during this time. The update is expected to last two hours, and live status updates can be found at https://status.arxiv.org.
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 1.0
token: : ANSWER; The latest article on the arXiv Blog, "Attention Authors: Upcoming Scheduled Maintenance to arxiv.org" (published September 16, 2025), announces that arXiv’s database will undergo scheduled maintenance on September 17th, 2025, from 7AM to 9AM EDT. During this window, users will be able to browse and search the site, but all functions requiring login—including submissions, account editing, and endorsements—will be disabled. Authors are advised that submissions will not be possible during this time. The update is expected to last two hours, and live status updates can be found at https://status.arxiv.org
